talk.start.para: —I would have thought we are in heated agreement that there is the world of difference between genuine counselling and a service being provided `with the sole or principal object of deriving sexual gratification'. Do we agree that there is the world of difference between those two propositions?

speech.para: If so, then the obligation is on the carrier to satisfy itself that this is a genuine counselling service. And, if it is not—and I would have thought overwhelmingly these things almost self-identify—the carrier would be required to treat it as a telephone sex service with all of the obligations imposed by the legislation. If it is not and the carrier has made reasonable inquiries and kept records of those inquiries, I cannot see how it would run foul of this law, because it would not come within the terms of 158J(1)(b).

talk.start.para: —If that is so obvious, can the minister advise why it is then necessary to exempt doctors and psychologists in that way?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Because therapeutic or counselling services provided by medical practitioners, on their face, are highly unlikely to be providing telephone sex services, whereas—
—Touche, on their face; you have just proved my point. So why is it necessary to exempt them in law, and how are the rest of the people going to prove that they are not—

—The rest of the people do not have to prove anything. If they simply say to the carrier, `This is the service we are providing; we are not a sex service,' and the carrier satisfies itself that that is so, it is not regarded as a sex service and it does not have to comply. It is pretty straightforward. Perhaps you think there is a lineball difference between `counselling' and `providing information with the sole or principal object of deriving sexual gratification'—that does not sound very much like counselling to me.

speech.para: I would have thought there is likely, in practice, to be the world of difference between counselling, which is probably likely to take quite a period of time, and telephone sex services, which I imagine are pretty short and sweet—particularly if they are timed local calls. So, in practice, there should not be any difficulty in distinguishing between the two. Any genuine service would have no difficulty in satisfying a carrier that it was legitimate and would, therefore, not be caught by the legislation.

talk.start.para: —I find it difficult to believe that this minister is for real in his analysis of the real world.
—I just want to come back to the question I asked which Senator Harradine answered. I wonder whether the minister can have a go. It comes to the question that Senator Margetts has raised.

speech.para: It seems to me that, in the absence of the telecommunications carriers being obliged to monitor what is going on, the sex line industry would simply say to the carrier, `Well, we are doing therapy.' Unless the telecommunication carrier listens in and monitors or tests—they might have to ring up and pretend they are somebody else—how else will they know whether it is a sex call or genuine therapy?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think a pretty reasonable starting test would be to look at the marketplace. People offering these services presumably will want to advertise them so that people will utilise them, and the form of words will be a pretty big give away as to the true nature of the service. If you are interested in a sex line service and there are ads to that effect, you are hardly likely to ring up a counselling service, and vice versa: if you are genuinely interested in counselling, why would you ring a sex line service? So I think there will be a high degree of self-selection.

speech.para: Where it comes to an obligation on carriers, it is only right and reasonable that carriers should have to make the initial judgment. It is not terribly difficult at the present time. No carrier has said to us, `We have enormous difficulty in determining genuine from purported sex counselling services.' The argument is simply whether or not it is onerous to require them to have certain obligations and what the impact of that regime might be. But I do not think anyone has seriously argued that you cannot tell the difference. Senator Margetts might not. Maybe they use naughty words and talk about rude things on counselling lines and, therefore, as far as she is concerned, there is no difference between counselling and sexual gratification. But I would have thought most carriers would be able to understand the difference quite readily.

talk.start.para: —That just does not make any sense, Minister. Are we saying here then that the telecommunications carriers do not have to monitor, are not allowed to monitor, or there is no requirement to monitor, but that they just check out the ads? If that is the case, to avoid this kind of action, why wouldn't a sex line put their first ad into the paper saying something innocuous like, `We do counselling'? Subsequent ads might turn out to be a different matter altogether; they may be sex lines.

speech.para: For instance, is Telstra required to comb through all of the advertising that goes on in every paper or magazine ad infinitum? There is quite a lot at stake here. As Senator Margetts has said, this is an industry which is currently worth $150 million. There is a lot at stake. Why wouldn't an organisation initially pretend to be about counselling and then go on with its real business at some later stage?

Senator ALSTON (Victoria—Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts) (10.07 p.m.)—I do not know what later stage that is. If they are in the business of making a quid, then presumably they are in the business of making sure that people have no misapprehension about the nature of the business. If you are seriously trying to make money out of sex lines, why on earth would you get out there and offer a counselling service?

The practical result will be that there is an obligation on those providing these services. They will know overwhelmingly what type of service they are providing and what type of business they are in. If they are telephone sex lines, as we understand the definition in the act, then they will have certain obligations attached to them. If somehow they pass themselves off in the way you suggest and the carrier has no reason to believe that they are not other than a genuine counselling service, and then it transpires or it is brought to the notice of the carrier that they are offering sex services without the requisite PIN, then the carrier would be expected to take action accordingly. So it is not a matter of monitoring every call; it is a matter of simply satisfying yourself that this is what it purports to be.

talk.start.para: —How does the telecommunications carrier satisfy themselves? This seems to me to be central.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I take it you do not mean that literally—or their employees for that matter. Are you somehow pretending there is no difference between counselling and sex gratification services? Are you saying that people might be genuinely confused about whether it is one or the other? I cannot understand that, because this is a commercial enterprise. You keep telling me it is a $150 million industry. Cocaine is probably worth a lot more than that, so maybe we should be even more concerned to protect the cocaine industry. But the fact remains that they are out there offering a particular service. I cannot for the life of me understand why they would want to offer it surreptitiously. But if they do and that is brought to the attention of the carrier, then the carrier has an obligation to make the necessary inquiries. If it is a genuine counselling service then it will not have a problem; if it is not, then it will.

—Minister, would you expect somebody to make a complaint to the telecommunications carrier; is that how it works? And then what: does the telecommunications carrier have to listen in on the conversations in order to make a judgment? It seems to me that we are dealing with a fairly enormous loophole in your legislation. All somebody has to do is to pass themselves off as something else for a short period of time and then proceed with whatever business they set up in the first place. I am just trying to get at what you expect the process to be of telecommunica tions carriers satisfying themselves that these services are not in fact those that your legislation attempts to cover.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There is clearly an obligation on the carrier to be satisfied that this is the genuine article.
—How?

—You seem to think there is an enormous difficulty in actually listening to a service, subscribing to it and knowing what it is. Maybe it is possible that you could listen to something and genuinely not know whether it is a counselling service or a sex line, but I would be amazed myself. But the legislation makes it clear that judgments do have to be made about whether or not this is a service:

speech.para: (b) having regard to:
(i) the way in which the service is advertised or promoted; and
(ii) the content of the service;
it would be concluded that a majority of the persons who call the service are likely to do so with the sole or principal object . . .

Of course it involves listening to it. You cannot make a judgment otherwise on the content of the service. Having looked at the way in which the service is advertised and promoted and having listened to the service itself, if you still have no idea whether it is counselling or otherwise then I would think that that would be an absolutely infinitesimal problem. It is certainly one that has never been raised with us, and I cannot see how it reflects the real world.

talk.start.para: —Minister, will the telecommunications carriers be able to tap telephone calls; is that what you are saying?
—Why would they need to tap them?

—Does the legislation make provision for that and, if it does, what are the implications for the Telecommunications (Interception) Act? What are the processes involved in, say, Telstra tapping that telephone? As I understand it, there is a procedure to be gone through to get permission.
—What do you mean by tapping? Do you mean listening?
—Well, you said that you have to listen in.
—Do you mean dialling the number?
—Order! Can we just have one speaker at a time, please. Senator Allison has the call.
—The minister just said they would need to listen in. Either they need to listen in as someone who is passing themselves off as a customer and so going through the motions—

speech.para: Senator Margetts interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Which is a difficulty, as Senator Margetts points out, if they do not have a PIN signed up, because they cannot do that. It is a serious question, Minister, and I wish you would address it. Either we are inviting telecommunications carriers to tap telephones, we are inviting them to pass themselves off as customers for the purposes of trapping organisations in this way, or we are not. It seems to me there is a major problem with the premise that telecommunications carriers can monitor without doing some of these steps. It is also fairly unreasonable, I would have thought.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I must say you puzzle me greatly. You seem to think that a carrier is incapable of dialling up a service or reading an advertisement in the newspaper and that, by definition, if a carrier listens to what is played on a publicly available line—one that is promoted—somehow it is eavesdropping but it is merely accessing the service if a citizen does it. It is just a nonsense proposition.

speech.para: Interception of private lines between two persons is a different proposition. The carrier does not need to listen in to an actual conversation to ascertain whether the type of service provided is counselling or otherwise. It simply dials up the service and it may not need to say who it is. It might be a recorded service. If it is a recorded service, then the material will speak for itself.

I think it is a pretty fail-safe test to merely look at the way in which the thing is advertised or promoted in the first place. You will not get much business passing yourself off as a counselling service if you are really in the sex lines business. There is no question here of interception or tapping or some sort of Big Brother intervention; it is simply a matter of an operator or a service provider having a number and making a service available, and the carrier, like any other member of the public, being able to access it and assess the quality of the material and the way in which it is promoted. You can do that as well as the carrier. Are you tapping it because you ring up that number? Of course you are not. Why should the carrier be regarded as intercepting by simply ringing up that number?

talk.start.para: —I would like to follow on from Senator Allison's line of questioning. I first of all point out to the minister that it is not an unreal scenario we are talking about. Depending on the state you live in, we have all experienced situations where sex services are advertised as massage services. I do not know whether people get a massage necessarily if they go to those services, but the reality is that escort services or massage services are often euphemisms for prostitutes or brothels. Basically it has been the case for a long time in Australia that the industry itself found ways of getting around restrictions in advertising and other legal problems. The situation may well be that people will understand very quickly what those euphemisms mean, so I think the minister is being very naive to suggest that the euphemisms will not develop very quickly.

speech.para: Perhaps the minister can tell us whether there will be a line on the budget. I know we have had various lines of inquiry in Senate estimates as to whether the use of government credit cards is acceptable for phoning phone sex lines. I wonder whether telcos will have acceptable budget lines, and whether we will find when we get to Senate estimates that Telstra, for instance, will have a budget line—if we ever see this—that says that there is a budget set aside for operators from Telstra to phone in and sample each of the potential or suspected phone sex services. How long will they have to be on the line, if it is a reactive line, to find out what kind of service it really is—whether it is one that is not acceptable or is acceptable? Considering the number of potential services that operate in Australia, what kind of budget would you be looking at to regularly phone through, put a PIN through and pay for a telephone service to find out whether it is in fact a phone sex line that ought to be restricted?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —As a starting point, Telstra does not get any appropriation from the budget. Maybe you want to argue that it should, but it does not, so we will not have that problem. Carriers who are offering these services are doing so for commercial gain; they therefore have inbuilt capacity to afford to test the services that are available. It is just another cost of doing business; there is nothing particularly unusual about that. If you want to argue that they should have pure profit from every cent they earn, the fact is that they have overheads and other costs of doing business and this just happens to be one of them.

speech.para: I cannot for a moment see that that is a particularly onerous obligation to place on them. I would have thought that overwhelmingly those offering sex line services would want to describe them as that, and that there would be very little passing off in the way that you described. Taking your analogy of massage parlours—we reverted to calling them brothels in Victoria some years ago—if there is a law against brothels but not against a genuine massage parlour and you expect the law to be enforced, you simply go around and inspect the services available. It is not a very difficult matter.

If you are telling me that you cannot tell the difference between massage and prostitution, then I suppose you have a problem, but in most instances the police who visit these places do not have any doubt at all about what is going on. So you do not have to take the advertisement at face value; you go and test the content—you inspect the goods. And that is what will happen here. It will happen at minimum cost to the carriers. They will still have the opportunity to derive very significant profits, but at least everyone will know what they are getting. I think we will have no difficulty at all in distinguishing between genuine counselling services and other fly-by-night operators.

talk.start.para: —I ask the minister what sort of advice he has had from the Office of Film and Literature Classification over this legislation.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not think we have had any advice. I am not quite sure what the relevance is. We have not had any advice from the AFL either. I do not see that the OFLC have seen any need to volunteer information to us, and we have not seen any need to seek it from them.

—The reason I raised that, Minister, is that if this had been able to have been dealt with in a few more days than two or three, we might have asked that question of them in the committee stage. But they have not offered up any advice, and you have not invited it? Nobody has commented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Not to my knowledge. I just point out in passing that the detail of these amendments has been on the web since last Monday week.
—The minister did not answer my question. I wonder whether he would.
—I did.

—I think this discussion is probably coming to an end—as fascinating as it has been—and I would like to put on the record the position of the opposition. The discussion has essentially been on the difference between the opt-in model and the opt-out model—the model supported by the Democrats and the Greens (WA). The opposition understands that we will divide on this when it comes to a vote. The opposition would like to put on the record that we support our opt-in model, with the amendments that we discussed earlier. We will not press our amendments to a division if it comes to that, but we do wish to place on the record the strength of our views concerning our amendments.
—I ask the minister: how long does he expect it to take to implement this legislation?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Are you asking how much longer we are going to sit for?
—My question was: how long will this take to implement? Could the minister indicate the readiness of the telecommunications carriers to implement this legislation.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —They were operating satisfactorily under protocols for some years until something triggered the break-out—I forget what it was—and it then got bogged down in ACIF for two or three years. There should not be any difficulty in them getting back to where they were some years ago. I do not think it would take more than a matter of weeks. I do not know that we have even had representations along the lines that somehow there needs to be a significant breathing space. We are giving them six months under clause 158N. I would have thought that was more than adequate.
—Does Optus, for instance, have the technology to go ahead immediately? Was that indicated to you in any correspondence?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I just said that they have got six months under the law.

—This seems to me to be an important line of questioning. It is my understanding that Telstra will take at least a year to restrict access to adult phone lines through an opt-in system. When the Senate is dealing with legislation which has a time frame, I think it is its responsibility to understand whether that time frame is achievable. The fact that the Senate has not been able to question Telstra or to verify whether this is achievable is relevant to discussion in the committee stage of this bill.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Telstra did raise some concerns about the time it might take, but I understand that it now accepts that it will be able to comply within the six-month requirement.
—Is that the case for Optus as well?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am informed that Optus has not raised any complaints.
—I will put the amendment moved by the opposition.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Could I just make a point of clarification. I thought—
—Now you are filibustering!

—I might have been in an earlier life when I sat over there, but that was very different. You remember what Senator Bob Collins used to say—that anything goes in opposition. I know you are carrying on the grand tradition. I thought these were our amendments that we are discussing—

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You want to get on with it? Let's get on with it then. I thought it was our amendments—
—The amendment is the one moved by Senator Bishop to the government amendment. I put the amendment moved by Senator Bishop.

—I am sorry, but could I just ask one other question. I actually have quite a lot of questions, but clearly the Senate is not of a mind to allow me to ask them. This one is important. In the legislation, who provides the PINs? What is the mechanism and the process?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Once the service provider is satisfied as to the identity of the subscriber, that service provider will issue a PIN which can be utilised thereafter.
—Are any privacy protections in place for that process?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not know. You are not really suggesting what the privacy concerns might be. Clearly, if you are required to prove your identity, that is obviously a gross breach of your right to remain silent, but you are seeking the service in the first place, so I would have thought it was a legitimate two-way obligation. There is no basis at all for thinking that carriers would want to disclose the identity of subscribers.
—Unless there was a big buck in it—they would for a quid.

—This is an industry that you strongly support. I thought you would have been telling me that they have been very responsible over a number of years. Certainly, they have been making decent money now for 10 or 15 years without those sorts of problems arising. It would not be in their interest to do it because they would immediately frighten off half the horses. There should not be any privacy concerns.

—I would like to get a few things straight. What I have been dealing with and arguing about in the questions I have asked and the position I have taken is the idiocy and the unworkability of the proposals. If that sounds familiar, it probably sounds a lot like online services as well. We are talking about a situation which is probably ludicrous in its actual workings and which may easily be gotten around by some, but it may make it very difficult for some people who have legitimate reasons for wanting to use those services.

speech.para: We are being asked as a Senate to make some sort of judgment on what you call fly-by-night operators. You call one industry an unacceptable fly-by-night operator. Let us just say that there are people who have services for couples who use explicit terminology. They may make a lot of money from those services for people who would otherwise have trouble—those who use explicit language or sell those services as a counselling service. People who are counsellors make money as well. That is the line of business that many people in the real world are in.
Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I want to make some comments tonight on the WoolStock legislation which was passed through the Senate today as non-controversial legislation. There was little time for the debate yesterday or today, mainly because all the hard work had been done outside the chamber, consulting with the people who had a constituent interest in the legislation. One amendment concerning the appointment of a trustee for non-identified shareholders was proposed by the government and accepted by the opposition and the Democrats. It was vital that the legislation was passed today, because the existing arrangements for Wool International expire on 1 July.

speech.para: This is legislation for the future. The past history of what led us into the present disaster for wool is of little importance now. The time for bone pointing has passed, and the lesson is not to repeat the mistakes but to get on and effectively manage a valuable asset which comprises the remainder of the stockpile. The aim of WoolStock is to maximise the value of stockpile wool and to do so in a way that is in the best interests of growers and gives them effective control of their future.

In October 1998 we announced our intention to privatise Wool International and to return ownership and control of the wool stockpile to the unit holders. The main outcome of the privatisation process is the conversion of Wool International from a statutory corporation into a company incorporated under the Corporations Law and the imposition of all of the Corporations Law on that new commercialised company. The new company will be known, as all growers know, as WoolStock Australia Ltd, and is expected to be established on 1 July 1999, replacing the statutory corporation, Wool International.

WoolStock's principal activities will be limited by its constitution to selling the stockpile—currently equivalent to 1.055 million bales of greasy wool—repaying the debt at around $230 million and returning any surplus to shareholders. WoolStock is not authorised to initiate alternative new business ventures. WoolStock's activities have been narrowly defined in order to ensure that it does not enter into new or riskier ventures that may erode its value for shareholders.

As part of the privatisation process, growers will receive one share in WoolStock for every unit they currently own in Wool International. The shares and units will be stapled together such that both shares and units must be sold together. The shares will be allotted to growers on 1 July and will place ownership and control of WoolStock and the wool stockpile in their hands. Some unit holders have used some or all of their units as security for loans. Any charges given over those units prior to 1 July will automatically attach to the same number of stapled shares. After 1 July growers will still be able to use their shares and units as security when borrowing money.

In addition to existing rights of shareholders, shareholders in WoolStock will receive new rights similar to those of shareholders in a public company. These include the right to be paid any dividends which may be declared by the company from time to time and the right to attend general meetings of the company to propose resolutions and to vote at those meetings, including in the election of directors or on changes to the company's constitution.

WoolStock has been structured to minimise the taxation obligations, and growers as shareholders will be very pleased with the result of the negotiations that have taken place, because the issue of shares in WoolStock will not impose a capital gains tax liability on the unit holders. WoolStock will be exempted from corporate taxation in relation to the disposal of the wool stockpile and income derived from investing the proceeds of the stockpile sales. Unit holders who are original wool taxpayers will continue to receive the unit distributions as primary producer income—a very big advantage to those primary producers.

The ability of some unit holders to claim small business rollover relief when selling their units will not be affected by the privatisation, provided that the unit holder's circumstances have not otherwise changed—another big advantage for primary producers. The small business capital gains tax rollover relief will not apply to WoolStock shares and the disposal of shares in WoolStock will be subject to the capital gains tax regime, which again can be of assistance to primary producers. Importantly, the privatisation process has been structured to protect the interests—as far as has been humanly possible—of the growers who are the unit holders.

WoolStock's activities will be limited to selling the stockpile and returning any surplus to stakeholders. WoolStock is not authorised to initiate alternative new business ventures. However, if shareholders want WoolStock to expand its objects they can vote to change the constitution under both the constitution of WoolStock and the Corporations Law itself. WoolStock's constitution allocates $3 million to investigate the possibility of establishing a wool marketing or processing company. Should any new venture prove viable, it will be financed separately. WoolStock will not commit or contribute financial resources to any new venture. However, WoolStock shareholders would be given the opportunity to subscribe to shares in any new venture, subject to the issue of a prospectus, as is normally the case in new venture capital.

For WoolStock the most important advantage to flow from privatisation is the commer cial flexibility to respond quickly to changes in market conditions. At this stage, WoolStock plans to commence sales from the stockpile immediately following the privatisation on 1 July, but I would suggest that those sales will be extremely modest and that the Commonwealth guarantee of the existing debt will continue for some time.

The board of WoolStock will seek to capitalise on the opportunities associated with the added flexibility which flows from privatisation. For instance, in the event of a wool price spike the board will not be constrained by a legislated selling program. Instead it will be able to evaluate this opportunity and respond in a way which maximises shareholder value.

WoolStock can only alter its objects and the restrictions on it by passing a special resolution at a meeting of shareholders. That requires a 75 per cent approval of a resolution and that is only after a postal ballot in which shareholders holding at least 50 per cent of all votes agree to a proposal. The restrictions on WoolStock changing its principal activities are very considerable indeed. It is very unlikely that it will happen. It provides the flexibility to look at alternative ventures that WoolStock might be involved in, but there is no way that WoolStock is going to be a company that is going to go off and risk its shareholders' money without showing cause and an appropriate appreciation of the risks involved.

The end of this very long process in the way that Wool International has operated since 1993 is that WoolStock has been broadly accepted by all the principal stakeholders. As I said, the legislation was debated today and yesterday and it was non-controversial in the main. The Labor Party have some problems with it—some is misguided and inappropriate—but at the end of this debate we will have the appointment of a responsible board, half of which has already been appointed; we have a board with powers to act only within the constitution of WoolStock and the Corporations Law in the best interests of shareholders; we have shareholders' rights that are clearly set out and enhanced by both the constitution and the Corporations Law; there is no requirement to fire sale the stockpile; and we have taxation arrangements that are as advantageous as is possible for growers. We can move on from here.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about a matter that involves both my electorate of the Australian Capital Territory and my federal shadow portfolio responsibility for sport. In December last year the ACT Liberal government decided on a full redevelopment of Canberra's Bruce Stadium so that Canberra could host Olympic soccer fixtures. At the time, Chief Minister Kate Carnell had projected that Bruce would hold 40,000 people and the agreement with SOCOG was based on this estimate. ACT Labor leader, Mr Andrew Whitecross, pointed out the fallacy of this estimation based on figures available after the Atlanta Games detailing soccer attendances for fixtures held outside Atlanta. Nevertheless, the redevelopment of Bruce proceeded on the basis of Mrs Carnell's optimistic estimates of the number of people who would attend Olympic soccer here in Canberra.

speech.para: Now we find that the financial situation regarding the redevelopment of Canberra's Bruce Stadium has been something of a movable feast. For starters, the redeveloped Bruce Stadium will only hold 25,000 people—15,000 fewer than the Carnell government originally estimated when they were determining the financial returns.

As my colleagues in the ACT Legislative Assembly found out during their estimates hearings, nobody seems to be able to work out just how much money is being spent and whether the ACT Liberal government has been transparent and up-front in this matter. When the ACT government decided to upgrade Bruce Stadium, the cabinet submission estimated that it would cost $27.3 million, of which $12.3 million would be funded from the government's capital works program. The remaining $15 million would be forthcoming from the private sector. Thus, the total cost ACT taxpayers would have to wear would be no more than $12.3 million. However, it seems that this amount was part of the Liberal's movable feast of financial disclosure. The $27 million soon blew out to $30 million. The question is: how much of this money will ACT taxpayers wear?

The central issue is whether Kate Carnell has breached the Financial Management Act by spending $16 million that had not been approved through the budget process. The Auditor-General apparently wrote to the Chief Minister stating, `strong anticipation by the government that the additional private sector funding would become available during the year, however this did not eventuate.' In short, because the ACT government received approval to spend only $12.5 million and the private sector part of the plan did not eventuate, the government went ahead with spending extra money without proper approval.

In her defence Mrs Carnell has argued that it does not matter how much public money you spend within a financial year, just so long as the books balance on 30 June. This is a very cynical excuse. To make the books balance she borrowed the balance of the money on 30 June and paid it back on 1 July. Consequently, Mrs Carnell appears to have spent money on Bruce Stadium that was not properly appropriated, and justified this by alleging that private sector funding will be forthcoming and therefore this money will be paid back. The ACT Liberal government does not seem to understand that you cannot just borrow money to facilitate your agenda without the proper approval of and due process in the Legislative Assembly.

During the ACT estimates hearings it was also revealed that the costs associated with the Bruce Stadium redevelopment seemed to be fluctuating on a daily basis. I understand that the Under Treasurer, Mr Lilley, originally stated that the cost of each seat at Bruce would be $1,600. Given that there are 25,000 seats at Bruce this would make the cost of the redevelopment around $40 million—a far cry from the $27 million we were told it would cost. However, literally overnight Mr Lilley revised his seat costing to $1,310 each, which—surprise, surprise—equates to $32 million, just $5 million over budget. It is therefore extremely difficult to ascertain the exact projections of revenue for Bruce and even the exact costs associated with the redevelopment. The ACT government agreed to the terms and conditions of hosting Olympic soccer in a cavalier manner without revealing the true social and economic costs to ACT taxpayers.

Furthermore, the conditions for hosting Olympic events in the ACT may impact on our local rugby league and rugby union competitions. At least four enclosed grounds are required to facilitate Olympic training preparations, and the grounds currently under consideration will need improvements before they meet the agreed standards. This may well result in a loss of facilities for the various football codes which will be close to semifinals in August next year. The ACT government has not satisfactorily dealt with this issue and there remains a great deal of anxiety about the potential loss of playing fields and the disruptions this will cause.

I welcome Canberra's role in the Sydney Olympics, and I fully support, and always have, the staging of soccer fixtures at Bruce Stadium. However, I am very concerned about the manner in which the ACT government has proceeded and their lack of transparency in revealing the true economic and social costs to the community. Mrs Carnell cannot continue to hide behind commercial-in-confidence rhetoric. She needs to detail the full costs associated with Bruce Stadium to the taxpayers of the ACT. This story is not yet over and I watch with interest as the Chief Minister is finally called to account.

One final comment: it is such a shame when this initiative is so positive and has so much to offer to a city like Canberra, to this place. It gave us a much coveted role to play in the Olympics. At the time Canberra secured these soccer rounds, it was seen as a great bonus. This great bonus has now been tainted by the actions of the ACT Liberal government in their treatment of this issue. I think it will reflect badly on them in the lead-up to the Olympics, and it will take a little of the gloss off what was a very positive and exciting initiative for Canberra.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk briefly about the issue of Greenwich University. I am pleased that Senator Carr is in the chamber tonight to hear this because this is about his outrageous behaviour in defaming staff at Greenwich University. I have a longstanding interest in education, particularly university education.
—Are they real staff?
—Yes, exactly. I will point out why they are real staff, and you will eat your words when I have finished this statement and the information provided by the university and its staff.

speech.para: Members of the Senate employment, education and training committee have had to suffer in silence for many hours, including from 11 o'clock to 4 o'clock in the afternoon at one estimates hearing when Senator Carr devoted those five hours of Public Service time—I do not know how much that would have cost—to defaming people and defaming this particular university.

talk.start.para: —Did he apologise?
—No, he did not apologise. But after I finish this he should.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am glad you think so. The staff of Greenwich University do not think so, and they have called for an intergovernmental inquiry between the United States and Australia over Senator Carr's behaviour in this matter.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Ten steps to courage, Senator. Go outside and say it. You have not got the guts, have you? You have not got the guts to go outside and say it.
—Order! Senator, your remarks are to be directed to the chair and not across the chamber.

—Through you, Madam President, Senator Carr is treating this place like a coward's castle to defame people who cannot defend themselves and to defame the reputation of this institution. Let us have a look at what he has done and the reaction to what he has done. I refer to page 35 of yesterday's Australian . The headline reads: `Island faculty outraged'. The article says:

speech.para: Greenwich registrar Sian Quantrill wants statements from Greenwich lecturers to be read into Hansard to "have the untruths and misstatements about them . . . put right".

The counter-statements from seven Greenwich lecturers contained in the letters are responding to an attack by Labor Senator Kim Carr. It claims the comments, made by Carr under parliamentary privilege, are defamatory.
On March 22—
and, I believe, again on 7 May—
Senator Carr referred to the distance-based institution on Norfolk Island as a "ridiculous, laughable and shonky pack of shysters, posing as a university".
Senator Carr questioned the authenticity of some of the university's courses, and the qualifications and associations of some of its lecturers.
He described the institution as a "denizen of murky underworld degree mills that cluster on the other side of the Pacific".
The letter to the Prime Minister says that a number of Greenwich people named by Senator Carr are US citizens who will have been "angered by the abuse of the parliamentary process".

"Two of them have suggested that the matter be referred to the US State Department in Washington so that it may be referred at an inter-governmental level with the Australian Government," Ms Quantrill's letter says.

It adds, members of the faculty "who have been named have asked that steps be taken by the Commonwealth Government to have the untruths and misstatements about them put right by the Commonwealth Government in the Parliament [principally the Senate]."

That is exactly what I want to do tonight. I seek leave to incorporate the seven letters that I have been presented with by the faculty of that university: Dr Jeanrenaud, Dr Lindgren, Dr Mertz, Dr Miller, Dr Patricolo, Dr Shealy and Dr Walston.

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted?
—Madam President, on the question of leave, I seek leave to make a statement in regard to this matter. Madam President, these documents have not been shown to the opposition.
—Order! The question at this stage is: is leave granted for the letters to be incorporated?
—When the documents are shown to the opposition with time for us to read them leave will be considered at that point. Leave is not granted.

—I am not surprised Senator Carr does not grant leave. He does not want this information on the public record. He stands in this place and defames people. They want to respond to Senator Carr but he will not let them. He is not even gracious enough to allow this material to be put on the public record. I will read two of the letters into the public record and that will show my point. The first letter is from Ms Quantrill, the registrar:

speech.para: Dear Prime Minister,

As you are aware some members of the Labour Party have sought to attack Greenwich University in recent months. They have descended to personally defaming members of our faculty by name, using parliamentary privilege.

A number of those named, are American Citizens who have been angered by the abuse of the parliamentary process. Two of them have suggested that the matter be referred to the US State Department in Washington, so that it may be referred at an inter-governmental level with the Australian Government.

We have sought to defuse the issue as much as possible by pointing out that the attacks have come from the Opposition, and that this is normal procedure in the Australian context. However, faculty who have been named have asked that steps be taken by the Commonwealth Government to have the untruths and misstatements about them be put right by the Commonwealth Government in the Parliament (principally the Senate).
I enclose copies of statements from seven of our faculty members, namely:
Dr. Jeanrenaud
Dr. Lindgren
Dr. L. Mertz
Dr. D. Miller
Dr. Patricolo
Dr. Shealy
Dr. R. Walston
We would ask that these be read to the Senate and incorporated into Hansard.
Sincerely,
S. Quantrill
Registrar
These are the ones that I have tried to table, which Senator Carr has tried to block. Let me read one from Dr Rick Walston, BA, MRel, PhD, DMin.

talk.start.para: —Which university?
—From reputable universities, Senator Carr. We will get to that point, and then we hope you will get up and apologise. I now read from the letter:

speech.para: Regarding comments made by Senator Carr with regard to Greenwich University in general and Dr. Rick Walston in particular.

It is with deep disappointment that I note that the good Senator does not investigate into matters worthy of being presented to the Australian Senate. I note with sadness that when he speaks of me, his only "evidence" is what he "has been told by another," as he indicates. Did Senator Carr speak to me personally? Did he communicate with me by phone, mail, fax, or email? Did he investigate the level of academic quality that our school requires? No, no, and no.

Without so much as checking to see if those things said were true, he stood before your great body and told you that I was the president of a degree mill. I would think that such a charge should be made only after careful investigation and the accumulation of corroborating evidence. Senator Carr did no such investigation nor gained any such "evidence"; a charge that I shall prove later in this letter.

Presently, I shall point out one of our more recent doctoral graduates for evidence to the contrary: James R. White earned his Master of Theology and Doctor of Theology degrees from our school. Dr. White is the author of The King James Only Controversy (which was his Masters thesis for his master's degree with our school) and The Forgotten Trinity (which was his doctoral dissertation with our school). Dr. White's academic works with our school have been published by Bethany Publishing House—a national publisher, and his books (including at least four more than the two mentioned) are being used in other, accredited, schools as text books. Now I ask you, is it common for diploma mills to require such academic work that rises to the top of the publishing world and becomes text books for other, fully accredited schools? Obviously not.

Let me now shift to our faculty and mention that the idea that our school is a diploma mill would come as quite a shock to our faculty member R. Brinley Jones , the President of the National Library of Wales, and Chairman of the Cathedrals and Churches Commission of Wales, and who holds his D.Phil. from Oxford University, U.K. His honorary degrees include the D.Litt. from Potchefstroom University, South Africa. And, it would also come as a shock to these other distinguished faculty members:
Samuel G. Andreasen, Ed.D. from Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ.
Rodney J. Crowell, D.Min. from Dallas Theological Seminary, Dallas, TX.
Larry V. Crutchfield, Ph.D. from Drew University, Madison, NJ.
Carl Judson Davis, Ph.D . from the University of Sheffield U.K.
Richard Brian Davis, Ph.D. from the University of Toronto.
Oliver Rice, Ph.D, from Trinity Theological College, Bristol, England.
Joel Berry Robertson, Ph.D. from the University of California, Los Angeles, CA.
I could go on but, let me ask, is it normal for degree mills to employ such fine academicians as faculty? Again, obviously not.
My last point is to prove my charge above that "Senator Carr did no such investigation nor gained any such `evidence.'"
How can I possibly prove that Mr. Carr simply repeated information "told" to him and that he did not investigate the charges himself?

And he goes on. I am nearly out of time, but he talks about the fact that they have changed the name of their seminary. Senator Carr, you referred to the old name, and your information is at least one year out of date, which shows you cannot even look up a web site to find this out. And, finally:

In conclusion, I cannot vouch for any other person that Mr. Carr so demonizes in his speech; however, if he did comparable "research" on the others he mentioned, then I would certainly caution anyone from simply accepting his charges at face value.
Thank you for this opportunity to respond.
Sincerely,
Rick Walston, B.A., M.Rel., Ph.D., D.Min
Step outside, Senator Carr! Coward's castle! Step outside and say it, and get sued! (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The comments made by Senator Tierney I am sure will be seen in the full light of the investigation that the Commonwealth govern ment itself has now launched into this degree mill. Might I say that some weeks ago, as Senator Tierney pointed out, I did draw the Senate's attention to the strange science of ornithology that does seem to exist in regard to Greenwich University. I, of course, was able to point out specifically the case of a number of galahs that seem to be so firmly entrenched in this particular episode. I was, of course, referring specifically to the galahs that have been creating havoc in Australia's most valuable higher education sector. The people I referred to in this context in particular were the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, and the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Macdonald.

speech.para: The issue involved the establishment of this virtual university known as `Greenwich' by an act of parliament of Norfolk Island. Of course, we all understand that galahs are the vandals of the bird world. As anyone who has kept one as a pet will know, their beaks are rapacious, they are instruments of destruction. So if two galahs make trouble, I ask you to think about just what sort of a problem a whole flock of them is making for Australia's higher education sector system.

Of course, this is the situation we now face. I say that the question of the operations of a number of universities are worthy of serious consideration by the Senate. I have drawn attention to the activities of the University of Asia, St Clements University and the Australasian Institute. I say that cyberspace is fast filling up with entities which are trying to pass themselves off as Australian universities. They are trying to hitch a free ride on our international reputation for excellence in education which has made our export industry in education worth some $3 billion a year.

This is an industry that is now to be compared with the size of tourism, wheat and mining as one of our great export earners. Now, of course, we have seen that these somewhat highbrow hitchhikers, these wanna-be Australian universities and institutes, have managed to get their own hold on what they regard as their version of `The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Cyberspace Galaxy'. What does it say? It makes it very simple: that Australia leaves itself wide open, in a virtual sense, to crooks and shysters who want to come in here and freeload on our high quality education system. `Go to Australia,' the guidebook advises. `Get yourself an Australian post office box or a room at the back of a grog shop and set yourself up as a university and hoodwink unsuspecting students from all over the world.'

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order that goes to relevance. This is absolutely disgraceful because I have set out clearly these people's excellent qualifications and this is not a degree mill. That has been stated emphatically and has been proved emphatically. Senator Carr should desist from going on with this defamatory rubbish.
—Order! Senator, there is no requirement for relevance in an adjournment debate.

—The whole exercise here is that you only have to advertise on the Internet that you are able to establish in Australia and the unfortunate students will be tricked into thinking that there is a real dinky-di Australian university. You can hitch a ride with a touring Australian education exhibition and trick the students in Islamabad or Timbuktu.

speech.para: We have seen today in the papers about one of these shysters, the Business Institute of Victoria—so-called. This thing is not registered as an education provider for overseas students under CRICOS, the official listing maintained by DETYA. Nonetheless, it took part in an Australian education exhibition in Pakistan and snared a number of students, who subsequently paid their $15,000 each and went off to study at this outfit's premises in Vanuatu—a back room in an obscure office block in downtown Port Vila. Yes, I said Port Vila—on another Pacific Island; not Norfolk Island this time. The advantage of Vanuatu is that the strict Australian student visa provisions do not apply in Vanuatu and, of course, an unaccredited outfit like this one can operate with impunity.

Of course, the other set of restrictions, the provisions applying to international education providers here in Australia—under the ESOS Act—are also lacking in Vanuatu. These are the financial safeguards that require the student fees to be placed in a trust. The prospect of that is that it is aimed to protect students when a provider goes under. So these poor Pakistanis, Vietnamese and the other students that participate in this so-called Australian university college at Vanuatu, the Business Institute of Victoria, have all lost their money. As for their tuition, we do not expect anything other than for them to be left stranded on the beach by the actions of people like this. What does this do to our fine international reputation? No good whatsoever.

We have seen here that Australian companies have set themselves up to take advantage of the relaxed immigration laws of a Pacific island state to exploit, in turn, Australia's international reputation in educational export. This is what happens in the case of operating out of Vanuatu, beyond our ironclad laws and safeguards designed to protect student interests. In the case of Greenwich University, that so-called laughable entity was legally established in the Australian territory of Norfolk Island with the clear and obvious purpose of passing itself off as a real Australian university. It has blatantly used the naivety on matters of higher education of the nine-member Norfolk Island Assembly.

What did Norfolk Island get out of it? Let me quote from a recent press statement that was made. They said they got `increased publicity'—terrific. They got tourism: `half a dozen local jobs and postage'—what an achievement! This is how their legislators have put it. They have increased publicity all right, and they have become the laughing-stock of cyberspace. And don't doubt this: there are more Norfolk Islands and there are more Greenwiches around—many more. What I am particularly concerned about in the case of Greenwich is the naivety of the nine yeomen of Norfolk, who have allowed themselves to be placed in a situation as a result of the lackadaisical irresponsibility of the galahs that have become responsible for the administration and protection of Australia's international educational reputation. Of course, they are the Australian ministers for education and for territories, not to mention their various legions of bureaucrats who are supposed to undertake the role on a day-to-day basis.

It transpires that the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald, has admitted that the department of territories did in fact consult DEETYA before advising their own ministers that there was no impediment to him signing off on the Greenwich University bill of Norfolk Island. This minister thought, as he said at estimates just last month, this was `not a major issue'. He says it was a matter of concern only to the people of Norfolk Island. But it seems that the contact between the two departments and in turn the principals of Greenwich University occurred at a junior level, according to DEETYA's own answers to questions asked of them through estimates.

Of course, I would ask: when did the secretary to the department express concern about these matters? Was it only after the Senate estimates hearing? Was it only after questions were raised by the opposition? I would ask: why was such a cavalier attitude taken to the unusual request from an obscure American institution about seeking to set up a university on Norfolk Island of all places? It was apparent that the alarm bells did not ring until the opposition raised these concerns through the estimates.

Madam President, I am sure you would be aware that the Sir Humphrey Appleby or the Yes, Minister tapes are being used as training vehicles for various public servants right throughout this great Commonwealth. What I find quite amazing is that we have now seen the whole full circle where public servants are coming along to the estimates committee to actually find out what is going on—because that is exactly what has occurred in this case. We have seen that the savage budget cuts meted out to DEETYA have rendered the department a shadow of its former self. This is why the department was only able to learn about these events through the opposition.

It is a very simple matter. How did the department find out about Greenwich's attempts to get into Australia through New Zealand? Through the estimates. What about the shoddy record of Greenwich University in the United States, how it has been chased from state to state throughout the United States and had its registration—for its various attempts to set up shonky programs—removed by the governments in the United States? How did that come out? Through the estimates.

What about the iffy qualifications of some of its staff, in particular the so-called Duke of Branagh or whatever he styles himself on as the great inheritor of the Russian imperial throne? What about the process that occurs where departmental officers appear to come to estimates to establish these simple questions. What about the worldwide resources of DEETYA? Why is it that the resources of one Labor senator seem to be able to establish these facts when the department cannot? I put a very simple proposition that this departmental blunder is probably one of the most monumental we have seen in many years. It is certainly bigger than the Wright family. It is certainly bigger than what we have seen with the ship of fools. We are entitled to ask ourselves about the ineptitude and the neglect of government ministers.

I say this to Senator Tierney: let people write to the Prime Minister and seek an apology because there will only be one apology—that will be the apology from the Australian Prime Minister about the incompetence, the neglect and the abysmal failure of government ministers in this government which has laid open the defences of Australia's higher education institutions to a group of people about whom the Californian government indicated that `Diploma mills that manufacture degrees based on the ability to write a cheque rather than the ability to master curriculum will no longer make the grade'.

talk.start.para: —In the very brief moments available, I will seek to read into the record another one of the letters that Senator Carr refused to give permission to have incorporated in the Hansard because they expose him for the sort of merchant that he is in trying to peddle defamatory material in parliament. Then, when it is found that it is not correct, he does not have the decency to make amends for it.
—When are you going to apologise?
—Senator Carr, you have had an opportunity.

interjection.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Carr!

—The people of Australia listening in tonight have just witnessed once again the disgraceful behaviour that Senator Carr goes on with in this Senate. This was also apparent at a committee hearing involving a Mr Vivian Buck during consideration of the voluntary student unionism legislation, where numerous defamatory statements were made. He has never proven any of those allegations, he did not provide any information in support, he has not retracted the allegations, nor has he reported it to the Privileges Committee. You see, Senator, when I make a mistake I have the decency to retract; you don't. Claudine Jeanrenaud states:

speech.para: I read the minutes from Australia's senate meeting on March 22nd 1999, and I have a few reactions. First, I must thank Senator Carr for indulging so brilliantly in insults, for this frees me to be rather direct myself. Though I don't think I'll be needing words such as "shysters" to be effective.
By snickering at the concepts of Alchemy or analysis of Fairytale, Senator Carr is advertising his ignorance of a whole field of psychology . . .
Senate adjourned at 11.10 p.m.

Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 504)

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 508)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) With reference to requests for disclosure of information under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 dealt with by the department since 3 March 1996, how many cases have been dealt with at the initial `decision-making' stage within: (a) 0-30 days; (b) 30-45 days; (c) 45-60 days; (d) 60-75 days; (e) 75-90 days; and (f) over 90 days.

(2) What is the average time taken at the initial `decision-making' stage to deal with the requests for disclosure of information under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 dealt with by the department since 3 March 1996.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) At an initial decision making stage (a) 117 requests were dealt with in 0-30 days; (b) 10 requests were dealt with in 31-45 days; (c) two requests were dealt with in 46-60 days; (d) six requests were dealt with in 61-75 days; (e) four requests were dealt with in 76-90 days; (f) nine requests were dealt with in over 90 days. In the remaining three cases the request was withdrawn before an initial decision was made.
(2) The average time taken to deal with requests at the initial decision-making stage is 27 days.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 509)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) At the internal review stage, where it was sought, (a) seven cases were dealt with within 0-30 days; (b) two cases were dealt with in 31-45 days, (c) no cases were dealt with in 46-60 days, (d) no cases were dealt with in 61-75 days, (e) no cases were dealt with in 76-90 days, and (f) one was dealt with in over 90 days (this case took 92 days).
(2) The average time taken to deal with requests at the internal review stage is 32.5 days.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 510)

(2) Of the cases relevant to (a) and (b) in (1), how many requests regarding access were: (a) partially successful; or (b) refused.
(3) Of the cases relevant to (a) and (b) in (1), how many requests regarding charges were: (a) partially successful; or (b) refused.

(4) Of the cases relevant in (2) and (3), how many of the department's written reasons for decision used, as grounds for refusal under the Freedom of Information Act 1982, a reference to Members of Parliament having access to parliamentary processes to seek information from departments.

(5) Is the department aware of any provision contained in legislation or departmental guidelines or practice where the applicant's employment provision can be, or has been, used as grounds for refusing access to documents and/or refusing to waive charges, other than that set out in (4).

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator Ellison
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Two requests were made by a member of the House of Representatives, (b) seven requests were made by senators.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Accrual Accounting
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 561)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 10 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What was the total expenditure on preparing the department for the move to accrual accounting for the 1997-98 financial year.
(2) What was the department's forecast for expenditure in this area.

(3) (a) In which instances were firms or individuals engaged to provide consultancy services associated with the shift to accrual accounting by the department; and (b) which firms or individuals were engaged.

(4) (a) What was the total number of days that consultants were engaged to provided this advice or services; (b) at what cost per day in each instance and (c) what was the total cost of each consultancy in each instance.
(5) (a) What is the estimated expenditure on outside consultants to advise on accrual accounting for the 1998-99 financial year; and (b) how much has been spent to date.
(6) What is the estimated total department expenditure on preparing for accrual accounting for the 1998-99 financial year.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Exact expenditure to move to accrual accounting for 97-98 is difficult to determine as the costs were, in the main, in-house staff costs. It should be noted that moving to accrual accounting has been taken to mean operating and reporting on an accrual basis, including establishing accrual budgets and policies.

Minor modifications to the existing Financial Management Information System (FMIS) were undertaken. This was partly because the current FMIS is an accrual system that was previously modified to operate in a cash environment, and a new FMIS (QSP) has been selected and is due to be operational 1 July 1998, on a full accrual basis.

In addition, one of the largest parts of the Department, the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service has been operating on an accrual basis since becoming a Trust Account in 1993. As has a smaller Trust Account operation the National Residue Survey.
(2) For the reasons outlined above the Department forecast a very minor amount in this area, in 1997-98.
(3) (a) For 1997-98 no firms or individuals were engaged.
The main reasons for external assistance have been due to:
* system modifications, as explained above; and that

* additional resources were required to establish an accrual budget and associated work in 98-99. This was because there are only a limited number of staff with appropriate skills and experience and a number were already undertaking other related activities eg. the FMIS implementation, external financial reporting etc.

(b) In the second situation when additional resources were required, a contractor from Acumen Alliance was used on a part-time basis to work on the accrual estimates project. In addition, an individual contractor working for WallRyan Investments has been engaged on a full-time medium term basis.

(4) (a) The total number of days that the contractor from Acumen Alliance was engaged to provide advice or services was 23, the individual contractor has been working with the Department from the beginning of November 1998 until present.
(b) The cost per day of the Acumen Alliance was $1,200, the individual contractor is $640.
(c) The total cost of Acumen Alliance' services was $27,600, the total cost for the individual contractor in relation to accrual accounting issues is expected to be approximately $51,200.
(5) (a) As mentioned above approximately $78,800 is expected to be expended on contractors for the accrual budget exercise.
(b) $63,400 has been spent to date in 98-99.

(6) The estimated total expenditure on preparing for accrual accounting for the 98-99 financial year is again difficult to determine, apart from the above costs the only expenditure was associated with internal staff costs. There will also be an exercise to update the Department's accrual reporting/accounting policies during this financial year, which will cost approximately $25,000. Negotiations with firms are currently under way.

To illustrate the scale of expenditure for in-house staff costs, for the 98-99 year approximately $90,000 has been expended in direct salary cost in creating the first accrual budget and work associated with establishing Opening Accrual Balances in the FMIS. There are few full-time resources able to be devoted to such reforms. However, to ensure that these reforms are covered off, other mechanisms of obtaining resources have been utilised ie. part-time team members or temporary teams, from within other areas of the Department who quickly return to their original area when the project is finished.
Question on Noice—Accrual Accounting

subdebateinfo.title: Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement: Forest Area
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 686)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 22 April 1999:

question.para: Following the Regional Forest Agreement, what is the total Tasmanian forest area:
(a) protected in dedicated reserves;
(b) in informal reserves; and
(c) in formal reserves.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) includes a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest reserve system that incorporates formal (including dedicated) reserves and informal reserves. These figures are based on the provisional RFA reserve boundaries. The total CAR reserve system on public land in Tasmania covers 2 700 000 hectares of which 1 246 000 hectares is forest, with the balance of the area made up of non-forest areas (eg. Buttongrass plains). Noting that the boundaries of reserves are still being finalised the following approximate areas are provided.
Total area of forest in dedicated reserves—0.630 million hectares
Total area of forest in informal reserves—0.155 million hectares
Total area of forest in formal reserves—1.091 million hectares
These figures were prepared from the jointly owned RFA data sets.

question.para: With reference to the food `aid' package being provided to the Tangerang region of Indonesia by the Victorian Department of State Development:
(1) What indicators demonstrate the existence of a `current food crisis' in the Tangerang region?
(2) What poverty and hunger indicators demonstrate the need for baby food aid in the region?
(3) What safeguards have been implemented to ensure the food will not be used as a breastmilk substitute by food recipients?
(4) What steps have been taken to ensure compliance with the World Health Organization (WHO) resolutions regarding free supplies of baby food?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill

answer.para: The food aid package provided to the Tangerang region of West Java is an initiative of the Government of Victoria under a Memorandum of Understanding with the Indonesian Ministry of Food and Horticulture.
